file_content.text: The shuttle to Dromund Kaas will be leaving soon, apprentice. I suggest you gather your slave, other belongings, and catch it.
This is only the beginning. With you as my right hand, we shall strike fear into the Empire's enemies.
I must convene with the Emperor and inform him of your progress. This shuttle pass will take you to Dromund Kaas. Meet me at the Citadel there.
Yes, master.
As fond as I am of this unyielding planet, it will be a pleasure to leave.
I'm glad to get off Korriban.
You will find Dromund Kaas to be considerably more stimulating.
Tell the Emperor I said hello.
My regards to the Dark Lord.
I'm sure he'll be thrilled.
Take the Twi'lek slave as my gift. Do with her as you wish. If she'll be of use, by all means, take her with you to Dromund Kaas.
Take the elevator to the Academy shuttle bay. There is a shuttle leaving soon. Be sure you're on it.
I am beside myself. Not only did you get the Twi'lek to cooperate, but you completed the task and claimed the ancient lightsaber.
Vemrin was not in my chamber as I instructed. I take it he sought to stop you and claim the ancient weapon as his own.
He tried and failed. Vemrin was nothing if not consistent.
Of course he did.
Regrettably, he wouldn't take "no" for an answer. I was forced to kill him.
I tried to spare him.
Yes, I'm sure it was difficult to bring yourself to do it.
He did. Now his carcass feeds the tomb's beasts.
The fool is worm food.
No doubt he will be as tough to digest as he was to defeat.
I knew he would confront you. The two of you were equally strong but exact opposites--who better to test one another's mettle?
It was all part of my plan--one final cataclysmic trial for my two strongest acolytes. Whoever emerged would be my right hand.
I'm disappointed. It should have been obvious I was superior.
You needed a test?
I do not rely on guesswork. I had to be sure.
If he was so strong, he could have been a valuable asset. Seems like a waste to me.
Why throw away a good man?
A necessary sacrifice. It had to be done to bring out your best.
Consider me educated. Now I know you're a master manipulator.
You're a sneak.
Yes, and don't you forget it.
Bravo. I see you may indeed become one of the strongest Sith in the galaxy. Your trials are over. You are now my apprentice.
I am your humble servant, master. I bow before you.
Command me, my lord.
Rise, my apprentice.
I can hardly wait to start, my master.
I rush to your service.
Good, because it's time to unleash you.
It's about time.
Mind your tone, my young initiate.
Ah, you've acquired the Twi'lek slave. Good. The lightsaber is almost yours. Now make her show you the entrance to the forbidden cave in the tomb of Naga Sadow.
Don't make me regret selecting you to get the special lightsaber. Retrieve the Twi'lek from the slave pens and find the forbidden cave in the tomb of Naga Sadow.
Now, I hope you fathom how fortunate you are to be singled out. If you become my apprentice, the galaxy will bend before you.
It fills me with pride.
You're not going to regret this, Baras. I was born to be Sith.
It's only appropriate.
Unleash me.
The lightsaber you will seek is old and powerful. It is housed in a forbidden cavern in the tomb of Naga Sadow where few Sith have ever set foot.
Almost no one knows how to find the secret entrance. But there is a Twi'lek in the holding pens who was caught breaking in there.
I hear she is quite willful. Take her and make her show you the entrance to the forbidden cave.
Of course.
You insult me, Baras. I do not need the help of a slave.
I can do it myself.
You will not find the forbidden cave without her.
That sounds like fun. I will enjoy bending her to my will.
Good, someone I get to break.
Yes, dominate her as you see fit.
Other acolytes seeking to complete their trials are sent to the tomb, where Academy laws are waived. They will try to murder you.
This final test will determine if you become Sith. So, bolster yourself. To set foot in the tomb of Naga Sadow is to breathe in death itself.
I like a challenge.
Appreciate the advice.
Ah, death. My favorite stench.
I will fill my lungs.
Go then. Retrieve the Twi'lek from the Academy slave pens, then seek your lightsaber.
We will see if you belong in the Sith Order, let alone deserve to be my apprentice.
The prodigal supplicant returns--and with all the shards from the tomb of Tulak Hord. Superb.
It appears Klemral was right and you were wrong, Vemrin.
It seems your hopes have been dashed, Vemrin.
Appearances can be deceptive.
Excuse Vemrin, supplicant. He expected you to fall on your face.
This is old hat for Vemrin. He should be used to disappointment by now.
He never learns.
I have little to no interest in anything Vemrin says or does, master.
Who cares?
Let me explain something to you, master, I have come to realize--Vemrin is a fool.
I know all about him.
Excuse Vemrin, supplicant. He didn't take kindly to you turning those young acolytes on him--even though they were only untrained novices.
He should thank me. Novices or not, I bet he had his hands full.
He needed the practice.
That was a trick I learned from Vemrin himself. I was just giving him a taste of his own medicine.
Turnabout is fair play.
I hope he's not holding his breath for an apology. A blowhard like him might suffocate.
I'm not sorry.
The tension is thick between you two. A great source of emotion to feed on. I wonder what will happen when it boils over.
But first, a matter to clear up: There is very little that escapes my scrutiny and I know, acolyte, that you provided Klemral with his shards.
So, since it was only by your tolerance that Klemral stands before me, I leave his fate in your hands. What should I do with him?
He still managed to succeed. The directive was by any means necessary. That kind of resourcefulness should be rewarded.
He deserves to be here.
Surviving this long is no small feat, so I agree that he should be allowed to live. But I do not find him to be Sith material.
He recognized his limitations, which has its own merit. But those limitations mark him unworthy to continue the journey to being Sith.
His training should end.
Yes, the next trial would destroy him instantly. While he is not Sith material, he is a survivor, so perhaps he can be of some use.
Klemral, I'm assigning you to oversee the Academy prisons. It's not a glamorous post but do your job, and you'll be respected here. Report to Jailer Knash immediately.
Thank you, my lord. Thank you both.
Take care, Klemral.
And to you.
Today sure is your lucky day. You got better than you deserved.
Fortune is smiling on you.
Thanks to you. Goodbye.
Your groveling sickens me. Prostrate yourself somewhere else.
Get out of my sight.
I won't bother you anymore.
He certainly lacks backbone, but perhaps he'll rise above that someday. Now, are the two of you ready for your final trial?
Klemral proved himself to be useless. If it's up to me, I say he should die.
Kill him.
No less than he deserves.
No! Please, I don't want to die!
Spineless. Now, are the two of you prepared to face your final trial?
Let's do it.
I can't wait to show you how ready I am, Lord Baras.
Nice, Vemrin. Most people have to get on their knees to lick boots like that.
Suck-up.
What must be done, my master?
As am I.
Then why don't you shut up and let the man talk?
Be quiet.
I love the sound of that--"final trial." The anticipation is killing me.
I'm looking forward to this.
Good. It'll save me the trouble of killing you.
Scared, Vemrin?
I'm worried about Vemrin. I sincerely doubt he's up for it.
My foe should stay home.
I'm gonna make you eat those words.
You're all talk.
I think I'll eat your heart instead.
I will kill you.
I'm not sure why you think I'm your enemy, Vemrin.
We don't need to fight.
You both stand on the precipice of becoming Sith.
Yes, such delightful anger--but enough for now. You both stand on the precipice of becoming Sith. You've earned the right to face the final trial.
But only one of you will have the opportunity to claim a special lightsaber and serve as my apprentice. I thought it would be you, Vemrin, but I've changed my mind.
What? I've done everything you've asked. Better than any of the others! The honor should be mine!
This is as it should be. Get used to being in my shadow.
I deserve this.
I'm sorry, Vemrin. I know how much you were gunning for this.
I feel for you.
Ignore Vemrin, Lord Baras, his world is crumbling around him.
Having a bad day?
Today, Vemrin is every bit your equal but the Force is stronger with you, acolyte, and there is a power sleeping within you. It was a simple decision.
Now, Vemrin, go wait in my antechamber for your instructions. This instant!
Now with that unpleasantness behind us....
What's next?
This isn't done. Mark my words.
I know we've had our differences, Vemrin, but good luck to you, nonetheless.
No hard feelings, Vemrin.
Know this--when you trip up, I'll be there.
Please, Lord Baras, I wish you'd let him stay. I want to see him cry.
No, come on, let me rub it in.
This? This is what you want to represent the future of the order, Baras?
You have yet to acquire the shards from the tomb of Tulak Hord. I suggest you hasten yourself.
Now, there are sacred ruins in the tomb of Tulak Hord. The ancient inscriptions that once adorned the walls of each ruin lie in pieces.
You will venture through the entire tomb, search all of the ruins, and bring me a shard from each of these inscriptions. You will do this or you will die.
I understand what's at stake. You've made it quite clear.
I hear and obey.
Uh-huh, sure.
Do not take this lightly, supplicant.
Dying is never an option. I have a strict policy against it.
Not much of a choice.
Then you had better be prepared.
Vemrin and my other acolytes have already been sent. There are no rules regarding how they secure the shards, and they will stop at nothing.
Fight your way through the tomb of Tulak Hord in the Valley of the Dark Lords, and bring me the shards from each of the ruined shrines.
What's this? The acolyte returns and with a bloodied weapon. I assume this means Tremel is no more. Give me his hand.
I'm concerned, supplicant. You left the overseer's rings. They could be valuable and serve as glorious reminders of your potency.
I thought it best to leave them as proof.
They're to ID the corpse.
Smart. They unmistakably mark the hand's owner.
What kind of greedy beggar steals trinkets from the dead?
I'm not a scavenger.
It is not greed to take what is won.
I don't need trophies to commemorate the past.
I'm not sentimental.
Foolish. We are defined by our victories and the quality of our victims.
Here. Take this one ring as a memento. Remembering the past can strengthen resolve and embolden the spirit.
I am impressed you had the fortitude to destroy him. You know, he thought of you as family. How did it feel to betray him?
It had to be done.
You mask your feelings well. As long as you don't suppress them.
We worked closely together. It was quite difficult, master.
I took it hard.
Nothing worthwhile is ever easy. Remember that.
It was a day I will long remember. I savored it completely.
It felt great.
Good. Feast on that. Not every kill will be as meaningful.
You have taken your first step to understanding the Sith Code. Peace is a lie, there is only passion. Through passion, we gain strength.
Through strength, we gain power. Through power, we gain victory, and through victory, our chains are broken. The Force shall set us free.
I will commit that to memory, master.
I hear you.
That's beautiful. Words to live by.
Inspirational.
Without those words, you will not be alive long.
By embracing the code and destroying Tremel, you have freed yourself from his shackles. And escaped his fate.
And now I'm bound by your shackles.
Different master, same fate.
You'll find they are a marked improvement, with much greater potential range.
Is that code really supposed to be meaningful to me?
I'm unimpressed.
Before the code, you had an indelible association with Tremel.
By killing your overseer, you've broken the chain that bound you to him... and to his fate. So you tell me, is the code meaningful to you?
You've made your point. I understand.
Yes, sir.
Tell you what, I'll think about it.
Fine. Maybe.
Ha. You have a bold spirit. Rancors must be broken before they can be ridden, too.
I'm glad to be free of Tremel.
I am delivered and saved.
That's more like it. I had a feeling you'd be a fast learner.
You continue to loiter? My eyes are already narrowing on you. Kill Tremel and bring back his hand. Immediately.
Most of you will not return from this endeavor. If you die, you will be forgotten. If you give up, you will be killed. Now, out of my sight.
I've got a bad feeling about this.
You should. This is the end of the line for you, Klemral. Just make sure you stay out of my way.
Look here, Vemrin, I see the upstart but no sign of Dolgis.
Dolgis wasn't Sith enough, and neither is Vemrin.
That lackey failed.
I just arrived, and it seems everyone already knows who I am.
My reputation precedes me.
Only a coward sends others to do his dirty work. Guess that makes you a coward, Vemrin.
Pretty gutless move, Vemrin.
So Tremel's last gasp made it all the way here. You're gonna regret stepping into my world.
Klemral, Vemrin, you have been dismissed.
Yes, master.
This isn't over.
Eventually you will have to admit I'm here to stay.
Show some respect.
It's never going to happen. Never.
We don't have to fight.
Once, perhaps, but not anymore. You are most certainly going to get hurt.
You're messing with trouble.
I underestimated you by sending Dolgis. It will not happen again.
Are you having trouble with acolyte Vemrin, supplicant?
It seems that way. I'm not sure why he's so bothered by me.
You could say that.
And why shouldn't he be?
I can handle it.
He is thoroughly capable of backing up his threats.
If he insists on getting in my face like that, he's going to have trouble with me.
He's playing with fire.
He has been hardened into a lethal machine.
Vemrin has paid his dues. He's fought a deck stacked against him to get here. You, on the other hand....
Let me get a closer look at you. Yes, as I suspected. Overseer Tremel has done you and this Academy a great disservice.
You don't know what you're talking about. Overseer Tremel did a fine job with me.
I disagree.
You don't have to tell me. I had to put up with the man.
I know what you mean.
And yet you followed Tremel's lead without question.
Forget Tremel. I excelled at every single task.
But I did so well.
Yes, you have been successful, that can't be argued. But Tremel has rushed your training.
Your warblade came early, prisoners flown in for your convenience, even a beast here on Korriban instead of offworld in the wild.
The pacing of the trials is deliberate. Only full immersion over time produces results. Your mind is soft, unhoned, undisciplined.
It was never my intention to offend.
Apologies, lord.
But it is offensive. To be presented with an acolyte who doesn't even have a rudimentary understanding of what it means to be Sith.
I don't think so.
I'll remember that. And someday, you'll regret those words.
Have your fun now.
I wouldn't regret destroying you where you stand.
The first month of trials should be dedicated to philosophy, conceptual tactics, understanding of the Sith Code.
Recite the Sith Code for me, acolyte, and explain its meaning in battle, war and politics.
I don't recall learning a Sith Code, my lord.
I can't.
Sure, give me a minute. Uh, well, you see there's the dark side, um... the light side, and uh... and there you have it.
[Bluff] I know the code.
Sure, give me a minute. See, there's the dark side--
[Bluff] I know the code.
Pathetic. I can read the lie from a nascent Force user with my eyes closed.
The only code I need to know is kill or be killed.
I don't need it.
Your ability is undeniable. But your readiness and understanding of the Sith way is woefully lacking.
I am your master now. Tremel was becoming lax before you ever arrived. His unwillingness to adapt to the evolving Sith paradigm has become a liability.
These are the actions of a traitor. Traitors are executed. I grant you immunity from punishment. Kill Tremel and bring back his hand as proof.
Of course.
I do not like the idea of killing him, but I'll do it if I must.
If I have to.
I do not make requests, supplicant.
It will be my extreme pleasure.
My dream come true.
Now, leave. I'm sure Tremel is still in his chambers. Don't return until you've killed him.
What are you doing here? I believe you are under Overseer Tremel's whip. You have no business here.
I'm going to give you the benefit of the doubt and assume this intrusion was an accident. But it would be in your best interest to leave.
